original_data.question:
A 41-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with abdominal pain. He says that the pain “comes and goes” throughout the day and usually lasts 20-30 minutes per episode. He can point to the spot 1-2 inches above the umbilicus where he feels the pain. He denies any feeling of regurgitation or nighttime cough but endorses nausea. He reports that he used to eat three large meals per day but has found that eating more frequently improves his pain. He tried a couple pills of ibuprofen with food over the past couple days and thinks it helped. He has gained four pounds since his past appointment three months ago. The patient denies any diarrhea or change in his stools. He has no past medical history. He drinks 5-6 beers on the weekend and has a 20 pack-year smoking history. He denies any family history of cancer. On physical exam, he is tender to palpation above the umbilicus. Bowel sounds are present. A stool guaiac test is positive. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsy to diagnose his condition.

Which of the following is most likely to be found on histology?

options.B: Urease-producing organism in the small intestine
options.C: PAS-positive material in the small intestine
options.D: Crypt abscesses in the large intestine

model_response:
The patient has peptic ulcer disease (PUD) due to an infection with Helicobacter pylori. The patient’s presentation is classic for duodenal ulcer pain. The pain is usually epigastric and relieved by food. The patient’s history of beer and cigarette use are risk factors for PUD. The stool guaiac test is positive, indicating blood in the stool, which is common in PUD. The patient’s weight gain is due to the fact that he is eating more frequently to control his pain. The mucosal defect seen on endoscopy is the actual ulcer. The biopsy would show evidence of H. pylori infection. Crypt abscesses are seen in infectious colitis. PAS-positive material is seen in Whipple disease. Urease-producing organisms are seen in some patients with gastrointestinal bleeding due to peptic ulcer disease.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

Care which provides integrated, accessible health care services by clinicians who are accountable for addressing a large majority of personal health care needs, developing a sustained partnership with patients, and practicing in the context of family and community. (JAMA 1995;273(3):192)
Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Occurring or done each day.
A precursor cell which gives rise to a fully differentiated cell of hematopoietic lineage.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
A traditional unit of length equal to 1/12 of a foot or 2.54 centimeters.
The pit in the center of the ABDOMINAL WALL marking the point where the UMBILICAL CORD entered in the FETUS.
Emotional sensations.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.

Flow in the opposite direction from normal, as the casting up of undigested food or gas from the stomach, or the backward flowing of blood into the heart, or between the chambers of the heart when a valve is incompetent.

An unpleasant sensation in the stomach usually accompanied by the urge to vomit. Common causes are early pregnancy, sea and motion sickness, emotional stress, intense pain, food poisoning, and various enteroviruses.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
Any of the occasions for eating food that occur by custom or habit at more or less fixed times.
Occurring or done each day.
The consumption of edible substances.
Condition changed and/or recovered
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
The act of linking together.
A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent with analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory properties
Substances taken in by the body to provide nourishment.
The traditional unit of mass. By international agreement, one avoirdupois pound is equal to exactly 0.453 592 37 kilogram, 16 ounces, or 1.215 28 troy pounds.
A meeting arranged with someone at a particular time and place.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
Excrement from the INTESTINES, containing unabsorbed solids, waste products, secretions, and BACTERIA of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.
An alcoholic beverage usually made from malted cereal grain (as barley), flavored with hops, and brewed by slow fermentation.
The time period comprising Saturday and Sunday, and sometimes considered to include Friday night.
A quantification of lifetime tobacco exposure defined as (number of cigarettes smoked per day x number of years smoked)/20. One pack-year is smoking 20 cigarettes a day for one year.
The history of when and what an individual smoke(s) or smoked.
A record of a patient's medical background regarding the cancer and cancer-related problems of blood relatives.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Applied to pain that is tender, i.e., elicited by touching the affected body part. []
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
The pit in the center of the ABDOMINAL WALL marking the point where the UMBILICAL CORD entered in the FETUS.
A noninvasive test that detects the presence of hidden (occult) blood in the stool. This is commonly performed to screen for colon cancer.
Involving advantage or good.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Procedures of applying ENDOSCOPES for disease diagnosis and treatment. Endoscopy involves passing an optical instrument through a small incision in the skin i.e., percutaneous; or through a natural orifice and along natural body pathways such as the digestive tract; and/or through an incision in the wall of a tubular structure or organ, i.e. transluminal, to examine or perform surgery on the interior parts of the body.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
The study of the structure of various TISSUES of organisms on a microscopic level.
